ID: 1111083430667632701
Taysom
01:00 AM
@Fmr. Senator Heinaluoma (S-NH)
Chairman, Ranking Member, and distinguished Members of the Senate General Welfare Committee, I welco
Welcome senator. Please tell us why we should consider your bill, S.4.
ID: 1111096299845062706
Fmr. Senator Heinaluoma (S-NH)
03:59 AM
@Taysom
Welcome senator. Please tell us why we should consider your bill, S.4.
Good Evening. When the Communications Act was created in 1934, Congress included an "Equal-time" rule for radio and television broadcasters to follow when allowing political candidates on their stations. This rule says that if a broadcast station allows one candidate to appear or speak on their station, the station must also provide equal opportunity for other candidates to do the same. This law has been persistent and enforced for decades but never amended to include any specific equal time requirements for broadcasters and stations to follow when presenting polls. This has resulted in news broadcasters and networks being allowed to easily get away with manipulating polls to exceedingly favor one candidate and even excluding declared candidates from polls which discourages voters from participating in that seasons election due to the candidate they favor not being shown in any of the polls broadcasted by these networks.

S.4 would amend the Equal Opportunities Requirement in the Communications Act to require broadcasters, when displaying polls from independent pollsters, to include polls which include the declared candidates and if one poll doesn't include a candidate, networks would have the obligation of making sure that those candidates are displayed in other future polls broadcasted by the network.
ID: 1111141469382778920
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
06:11 PM
@Taysom
Welcome senator. Please tell us why we should consider your bill, S.4.

@Konnor Harris
*arrives to the <@&1107330499975860224>*
Welcome senator. You are here to speak on S.10, to explain to the committee it‚Äôs propose and importance. You can start whenever you‚Äôre ready.
ID: 1114659025838153789
Konnor Harris
09:11 PM
Well hello colleagues! As the author and sponsor of S. 10, I‚Äôm glad to testify on its behalf.

First, as stated in the bills long title, the bill seeks to protect the civil rights of many people within the realm of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993. This is done by creating an exception for the applicability of the RFRA in cases where it‚Äôs application would cause undue harm to another party, or where other appropriate civil rights legislation applies.

Second, the reason I feel that such a bill is necessary and needed is to ensure that the Code of the United States is alignment with our Constitution and national values. Since the RFRA was enacted thirty years ago, we have become a society that is much more tolerant and accepting of differences, be it sexual orientation and gender identity to religious affiliation or the lack thereof.

I‚Äôm glad to answer any questions.

Taysom Stolworthy
10:51 PM
@Mangos=6 Mustard=7 67 6+7 13
The floor is now open for debate for the next 9 hours. <:HammerTime:712031635331219586>
What would "diversity training" entail?
ID: 1134619255418142822
Mangos=6 Mustard=7 67 6+7 13
11:31 PM
@Taysom Stolworthy
What would "diversity training" entail?
Diversity training in police training is aimed at promoting understanding, respect, and inclusivity among law enforcement officers when interacting with individuals from diverse backgrounds and communities. It helps reduce biases, build empathy, and enhance effective communication skills to foster positive community relations and equitable policing practices.
specific content of diversity training may vary, but it often includes the following elements:
ID: 1134629165212106854
Mangos=6 Mustard=7 67 6+7 13
11:31 PM
1. Cultural Awareness: Participants learn about different cultures, ethnicities, religions, and social backgrounds to become more aware of diversity within society.
2. Unconscious Bias Recognition: Training helps individuals recognize and address their unconscious biases that may influence their perceptions and behaviors toward others.
3. Inclusive Language: Participants are taught to use language that is respectful and inclusive, avoiding terms that may perpetuate stereotypes or offend others.
4. Understanding Privilege: Discussions on privilege and its impact on social interactions and opportunities may be included to promote awareness and empathy.
5. Effective Communication Skills: Training focuses on enhancing communication and interpersonal skills, emphasizing active listening and respectful dialogue.
6. Conflict Resolution and Mediation: Participants may learn strategies for resolving conflicts in a diverse and multicultural context.
7. Respect for Differences: The training emphasizes the importance of treating all individuals with dignity and respect, regardless of their background or identity.
8. Legal Framework: Participants may receive information on laws and regulations related to diversity, discrimination, and equal rights.
9. Community Engagement: For police officers, diversity training may include components related to community policing and building positive relationships with diverse communities.
10. Scenario-based Exercises: Practical exercises and role-playing scenarios may be used to apply the principles learned during the training.
11. Continued Learning: Ongoing training and opportunities for continued learning are often encouraged to reinforce the importance of diversity and inclusion.
ID: 1134629267234361385
Mangos=6 Mustard=7 67 6+7 13
01:50 PM (edited)
The period of debate has ended the bill is now up for voting. For 9 hours

Mr. Chairman, I introduced this bill on the behalf of former Senator Claire-Dawson (with some minor edits) because I believe in the importance of protecting women‚Äôs access to safe contraceptives.

Like most Americans, I believe that the road to ending abortions is to ensure that women can prevent unwanted pregnancies in the first place. President Bill Clinton said it best when he said that abortions should be: ‚ÄúSafe, Legal, and Rare.‚Äù

This legislation is incredibly important for the health of women everywhere. That is why I am asking my fellow senators to vote Yes on S. 2

S.2 is before the Committee for a period of 9 hours, or until cloture is invoked. <:HammerTime:712031635331219586>

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1U2qjXPdK4mbFdiJuTjpDjDCsiMYY2aAb/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=108070132828056405549&rtpof=true&sd=true
S.2 - Safe Contraception Access Act.docx
S. 2 To protect a person‚Äôs ability to access contraceptives and to engage in contraception, and to protect a health care provider‚Äôs ability to provide contraceptives, contraception, and information related to contraception. IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES NOVEMBER 12, 2023 Mrs. Dawson-Lockh...
ID: 1173687424677847130
grace
06:27 PM
The chair offers prepared remarks on the bill.

The constitutional right to access contraceptives has long been recognized by the Supreme Court. First recognized for married couples in 1965 with the case Griswold v. Connecticut, and expanded to unmarried people in 1972 with the case Eisenstadt v. Baird, this right has long been recognized and protected.

As a woman currently on birth control, a form of contraceptives, I have a unique perspective on the subject matter at hand. It is crucial to protect the right to use contraceptives.

While I agree with the President‚Äôs statement that Griswold is current court precedent, it only establishes that right. As we know, there are some who will ignore current Court precedent, such as Attorney General Swanson during his time as Governor of Lincoln. He penned an executive order restricting abortions within the Commonwealth- my home state- in June of this year. You cannot say that court precedent exists when you willfully ignore it.

This Act does not only say that there is a right to access contraceptives, it expands it. The right to bodily autonomy is something that I as a mother and woman will always protect, and it starts with this bill.

I urge my colleagues in this Committee and in the Senate as a whole to read the bill in full. If there are amendments you would like to make, please propose them. If you have concerns about the bill, please voice them instead of just voting nay. Thank you.
ID: 1173690691705122926
grace

The chair moves to cloture the bill.

Wilson
05:20 PM
Debate is open on S.1.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Hsrw7iLefCGgcU_vv6vh_QrkfaWX2c_AMEZwH2TCNPc/edit?usp=sharing
(S.1) EMPERIO Act of 2023
ID: 1185994946835132426
the chairman of the server
06:56 PM
The Senate General Welfare Committee shall come to order <:senategavel:1088936076040749140>
ID: 1190367665018122331
the chairman of the server
06:56 PM
Members shall state their presence for the ascertainment of a quorum. @Senate General Welfare Committee
ID: 1190367799512662067
the chairman of the server
06:56 PM
The Chair marks themselves as present.
ID: 1190367875958067270
Mac
06:57 PM
Present
ID: 1190367894626910288
Ducky Anka
07:16 PM
Present
ID: 1190372909294821477
Harmon Rabb (D-RU-1)
07:18 PM
@the chairman of the server
The Chair marks themselves as present.
Present
ID: 1190373244360994906
the chairman of the server
05:49 PM
A quorum is present and the Committee is now in order to conduct business.
ID: 1190713290410705037
the chairman of the server
05:55 PM
With the Committee now functional, the previously referred S. 1 is now open for debate. The Committee is in non-strict order and members can speak without recognition.
ID: 1190714892995530792
the chairman of the server
06:21 PM
As the author of S. 1, I would like to introduce the Committee to this bill and what it seeks to accomplish.

It is common knowledge that our electricity grid is on the verge of collapsing, with it, according to several independent studies, completely unable to serve the U.S. in the coming decades with energy consumption only destined to increase drastically. Though this Congress has already acted several times to increase grid capacity by authorizing or subsidizing the construction of new energy-production facilities, many of which are renewable, there is still a massive lack in the infrastructure to actually transmit this energy across the country, and in particular, across the three major grids that exist within the U.S., which have been built to have very little interconnection and interoperability.

This requires the construction of major interstate transmission facilities that take power produced in one corner of the country to another. For example, in Pacifica, the subdivision of California has, for many years now, struggled to meet energy demand during seasonal surges, such as those during the summer. However, transmission projects such as the future TransWest Express would allow States like Wyoming and its many renewable wind farms to sell its surplus green energy to regions like California when it's needed the most. This is one such case where interconnections create massive gains for the States involved and the country as a whole.

However, there are a number of regulatory hurdles which continue to bring our transmission infrastructure to its knees, in particular, the regulation concerning the siting and approval of new interstate transmission facilities. Currently, proposals for new transmission lines across State borders‚Äîwhich are well within the Federal Government's enumerated rights to regulate‚Äîrequire adherence to a draconian and overly complicated process that requires approval by every State, municipality, county, and practically every further subdivision you could think of, that the line passes through. This process can take years and decades to complete, a stark inefficiency in our current regulatory framework which continues to squander time our grid simply doesn't have. There is then a genuine national interest in federalizing this process‚Äîonly for interstate lines‚Äîsuch that the time taken to obtain Right of Way is reduced significantly. This bill achieves exactly that.

Further, the submission of lengthy EIS and ES reports pursuant to certain antiquated provisions of the National Environmental Policy Act can also take up to a full decade to complete. These, in particular, are quite ironic, as the construction of transmission lines connecting renewable energy-generating facilities is one of the greatest tools we have to achieve our environmental targets. The benefit of their construction in the overwhelming majority of cases outweighs any environmental impacts, and given the extraordinary national interest that is vested in their expeditious construction, such a lengthy process is not needed. As such, this bill codifies a statutory categorical exclusion from the requirements of NEPA to be granted to projects by the DOE/FERC in circumstances where the environmental impact is minimal or where expedited construction is absolutely necessary.

In addition, to incentivize industry partners to apply for licenses to build new transmission facilities, this bill creates a cost-recovery scheme that enables a public utility or permit-holder developing an interstate transmission project to recover, either partially or in whole, the cost of such projects, as long as it is completed in a satisfactory manner.
ID: 1190721304647696504
the chairman of the server
06:23 PM
Additionally, the bill also allows for the DOE/FERC to pre-emptively approve projects (and follow a pre-emptive siting process as well) that have been internally developed, further directing that such proposals (and relevant licenses/permits) be awarded to private industry in a manner that DOE/FERC sees fit, such as competitive bidding, or otherwise.
ID: 1190721850796425296
Harmon Rabb (D-RU-1)
06:39 PM
I would like to speak with some experts before I can vote on this bill.

I move to invite the chairman of Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to a hearing on the issue of this bill.
ID: 1190725987089002566
Harmon Rabb (D-RU-1)
06:40 PM
@the chairman of the server
ID: 1190726011239809054
the chairman of the server
07:15 PM (edited)
One bill that has previously sought to tackle the deficiency in our country's transmission facilities is the *Clean Energy Future Act of 2022*. However, its provisions have been so poorly worded and executed that it may as well have never been written. Section 4 and 5 of that bill are relevant to this discussion and I would like to make the case to this Committee that it is in our nation's interest to repeal these particular sections.

The authorization of an almost quarter of a trillion-dollar investment into our energy infrastructure, condensed into a mere 10 lines of provisions, along with vague and poorly articulated goals and lofty timelines, is not only a disgrace but is also causing substantial harm to our country as long as it remains in effect.

For example, its amendment of the Federal Power Act considers an energy transmission project satisfying certain requirements to be, and I quote, "automatically approved", without defining what "approval" here means. (does this supersede State regulation? does this supersede all other Federal regulation such as those pertaining to the Bureau of Land Management, NEPA, section 106 review under the National Historic Preservation Act, section 404 review under the Clean Water Act, or review under the Endangered Species Act, and a _whole host of other__essential__ Federal regulation_). This is, by all means, extremely dangerous and vague wording.

More glaringly, however, this bill explicitly specifies construction requirements, down to the specific aluminum alloy to be utilized. This constitutes a clear instance of congressional overreach and presumption in that it completely dismisses the expertise of the DOE, FERC, and private industry in determining the optimal methods for constructing transmission facilities. Bureaucracy exists for a reason! We in Congress do not have the expertise to regulate such granular details. This is creating further red tape and needless regulation that can only serve to stifle private industry efficiency and innovation.

Among other faults, this bill directs "the government" to construct new transmission lines in an amount that doubles‚Äîalmost triples‚Äîexisting transmission capacity within a mere 10 years, and‚Äîget this‚Äîdoes this by attaching a map of the U.S. with lines drawn over it to "indicate" where these lines will go, without _any_ additional information regarding the corridors that these lines go through, or otherwise. Since when do we authorize hundreds of billions of dollars worth of investments based off of arbitrary lines on a map? Practically every line of the relevant sections of that bill is deeply flawed and it is my belief that this Committee should amend S. 1 to include a provision that repeals those sections of the CEFA in their entirety.
ID: 1190734842606923916
the chairman of the server
07:20 PM
@Harmon Rabb (D-RU-1)
I would like to speak with some experts before I can vote on this bill. I move to invite the chairm

One bill that has previously sought to tackle the deficiency in our country's transmission facilitie
For the foregoing reasons, the Chair moves to make the following amendment:

S. 1 is amended in section 6 by appending the following subsection:

> (c) CEFA REPEAL.‚Äî
> (1) IN GENERAL.‚ÄîThe Clean Energy Future Act of 2022 is amended by striking section 4 and section 5 in their entirety.
> (2) RETURN OF FUNDS.‚ÄîAny and all funds, pursuant to authorizations made under section 13(a) of the Clean Energy Future Act of 2022, that remain unobligated as of the passage of this Act shall be returned to the General Fund of the U.S. Treasury within six months of the passage of this Act.

ID: 1196822176251261088

ID: 1199386363108266085
the chairman of the server
04:47 PM
On S.4, I'd like to start my remarks by stating that I have very little experience with housing policy, so do kindly excuse me if I misunderstand something. I have no qualms with the rationale of the bill and what it seeks to execute, I'm more concerned with the way its goes about executing things. To that end, I only have a few sincere questions for the Honorable Minority Leader.

Firstly, in re section 3: what exactly does "there shall be new housing units constructed [...]" mean? Is the Federal Government personally going to be building affordable/public housing units, or is it merely making funds available to States and local governments for the same. If it is the former, exactly what constitutional authority would we, as a Congress, be exercising to legislate the same? If it is the latter, I do not see explicit wording indicating that funds are being made available, though, as I do admit, I'm not familiar with the U.S. Code sections its amending.

Then, with respect to addition targets, the formula does seem rather arbitrary to me, so some clarification or further reading justifying its use would be appreciated. Also, I'm not sure what you mean by "Faircloth Act" in "[...] under the now-repealed Faircloth Act". Do you mean the Faircloth Amendment under what used to be 42 U.S.C. 1437g(g)? To that end, the "Faircloth Number" mentioned in the bill doesn't make much sense to me, either, partly because in statute there is no such thing (please do correct me if I'm wrong). The Faircloth Number, as far as my understanding goes, is a colloquialism for a baseline number of public housing units in a particular public housing agency's inventory, as of October 1, 1999. This is what's written, or was, written in statute previously. Further, as a result of this, there is no singular Faircloth Number, which seems to conflict with the idea of the Federal Government, or the HUD Secretary, calculating a national addition target.
ID: 1199395084119048283
the chairman of the server
04:50 PM
All in all, I feel that this section is a bit ill-defined, but again, I'm not familar with housing policy.

Also, I'm struggling to understand:

> (c) COSTS.‚ÄîUnits shall not exceed the average cost per square foot for construction in the local area of the project. General Contractors shall provide the highest quality of work and materials possible under this number.

I have a general idea of what it means, but I'm not sure. The wording appears to be slightly confusing.
ID: 1199395764904919230
the chairman of the server
04:51 PM
Other than that, the bill looks good.
ID: 1199395916931674182
Konnor Harris
05:42 PM
@the chairman of the server
All in all, I feel that this section is a bit ill-defined, but again, I'm not familar with housing p
Thank you Mr. Chairman, allow me to answer:

With respect to section 3, the United States Government has constructed buildings before. The General Services Administration has done a plethora of construction here in DC, which while not a state, shows that we have the authority to construct. The intent of the bill is to appropriate money to HUD to build the units. HUD may choose to either acquire the land and construct the units, or can disperse the funds to local Public Housing Authorities. It‚Äôs not an either or; it‚Äôs both.

I will concede a drafting error with the misnaming of the Faircloth Amendment; I‚Äôll be speaking to the drafting service on that one. The definition of the Faircloth Number is a derivative of the Faircloth Amendment; the number has been reported as 1.42 million from the numbers calculated from HUD‚Äôs records.

Subsection c is a guard against price gouging. Before my time in public office, I worked in the Architecture industry. While many contractors are honest, some contractors have a history of price gouging. This is more of a safety measure for public funds.

Thank you for your questions; I do want to ask if we should include legal penalties for violations of subsection (c)?
ID: 1199408913158766673
Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
06:02 PM
Will be reading myself soon.
ID: 1199413797576786031
Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
06:17 PM
So on its face for subsection c, I would say just termination of contract is most appropriate, or prohibition from bidding for a certain number of years. I'm not entirely sure on something like a fine though, I lean no.

> With respect to section 3, the United States Government has constructed buildings before. The intent of the bill is to appropriate money to HUD to build the units. HUD may choose to either acquire the land and construct the units, or can disperse the funds to local Public Housing Authorities. It‚Äôs not an either or; it‚Äôs both.
Hmm. I'm not too convinced with the argument for the Federal Government's direct construction of housing units. D.C. is a special case. I'll definitely do some further reading on the matter. The dispersing of funds to local PHAs is something I can get behind, however.

> I will concede a drafting error with the misnaming of the Faircloth Amendment; I‚Äôll be speaking to the drafting service on that one. The definition of the Faircloth Number is a derivative of the Faircloth Amendment; the number has been reported as 1.42 million from the numbers calculated from HUD‚Äôs records.
Is this "Faircloth Number" then just the total number of public housing units available across all of the country's PHAs? Given that it's been historically used as a baseline, what year are we using as a reference? Regardless, because it's primarily regulatory/departmental terminology, that doesn't currently exist in the U.S. Code, I think there may be value in amending S.4 to rigorously define this constant.

> Subsection c is a guard against price gouging. Before my time in public office, I worked in the Architecture industry. While many contractors are honest, some contractors have a history of price gouging. This is more of a safety measure for public funds.
Ah, I see. Thank you.

My thought is that each group of professionals meet monthly, of which the board meets as a whole quarterly to work out items where professions conflict; it happens rather frequently.

Is there code that requires that the President appoints those persons? I don‚Äôt believe that it would be, but I‚Äôm not married to the idea of the Secretary doing the appointment if they do.

The Ranking Member moves to make the following amendment.

I move to amend H.R.3 as follows, with the stricken text crossed out and new text in bold, in Section 5000E.

"‚ÄúSEC. 5000E. EXCESS SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENCES.
‚Äú(a) In General.‚ÄîThere is hereby imposed on each covered taxpayer for each taxable year a tax in an amount equal to the product of‚Äî
‚Äú(1) $10,000, and
‚Äú(2) the excess of‚Äî
‚Äú(A) the number of single-family residences owned by the taxpayer as of the last day of the taxable year, over
‚Äú(B) ~~ 50~~ 35."
ID: 1201716883947003944
Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
02:35 AM (edited)
Motion to Amend as follows:

"‚ÄúSEC. 5000E. EXCESS SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENCES.
‚Äú(a) In General.‚ÄîThere is hereby imposed on each covered taxpayer for each taxable year a tax in an amount equal to the product of‚Äî
‚Äú(1) $10,000, and
‚Äú(2) the excess of‚Äî
‚Äú(A) the number of single-family residences owned by the taxpayer as of the last day of the taxable year, over
‚Äú(B) ~~ 50~~ 35."

Question by the Chair: Shall the above amendment to H.R.3 be agreed to?

The Ranking Member votes aye.

Mr. Chairman, the Great Lakes Mass Marking is a bill focused on making technology more accessible for agencies and groups to help track and monitor the current health of fisheries in the Great Lakes, and seek to preserve current sport fish populations, and builds upon a prior program from 2010 that was successful in its aims.

Mr. Chairman, I can speak more about S.2 and S.3

This bill gives 25 million dollars in grants to community college agriculture and natural resources programs across the country. Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
11:26 PM
Mr. Chairman, I obviously support both pieces of legislation.

First, S.4 seeks to provide grants to youth organizations to continue the great work they do in rural and small towns.

S.5, seeks to promote precision agriculture, with the public and private sector working together to promote precision agriculture technology.

Precision agriculture, also called satellite farming, aims to make farm production more efficient, which in turn, helps the environment.

Corey Clark
09:10 PM

ID: 1214318970664914975
Konnor Harris

ID: 1214319169907204147
Konnor Harris
09:12 PM
Allow the record to reflect the nominee answered in the affirmative.

@Senate General Welfare Committee, this hearing shall continue for 24 hours or until a motion to cloture is made and properly seconded. The hearing may be extended by motion or via unanimous consent. <:HammerTime:712031635331219586>
ID: 1214319571264081981
Konnor Harris
09:25 PM
Does the nominee wish to make an opening statement?
ID: 1214322749926023228
Corey Clark
09:25 PM
I do.
ID: 1214322785057378414
Corey Clark
09:25 PM (edited)
Thank you Chairman Harris-Charest, Ranking Member Noah, and distinguished Members of the Committee.

Good afternoon to all, I am Corey Clark, and I am honored to have been nominated to serve as the next Archivist of the United States. I would like to thank my wife Jayla for supporting me during my career in both my day-to-day jobs and government positions. I am happy to be back in this wonderful committee room, but instead on the other side. *chuckles*

I believe everyone here is already familiar with me. Over my years of service to my Commonwealth in the Senate, my records show that I served concurrently with each one of you. My devotion towards the American people started back in my collegiate years at Yale University where I pursued a dual-degree in Political Science and Education. After I completed my undergraduate studies, I went on to law school at Yale Law.

Visiting the National Archives back in eighth grade was one of the most wonderful experiences I have ever felt. The experience that my class and many others felt that day is what I wish to preserve and expand if confirmed. Increasing interest of students with the founding documents and other historical artifacts and documents is something that can help unify us all. The National Archives and Records Administration is a special part of our federal government as it preserves and retains the building blocks of our country‚Äôs principles. Providing our citizens with 24/7 online access to the nation‚Äôs history is one of the most critical tasks the federal government achieves through NARA.

I am open to any questions you may have, and thank you for having me.
ID: 1214322884189757521
thefalconegeneral
09:29 PM
Why do you believe you're qualified for the position you have been nominated to
ID: 1214323868920057856
Corey Clark
09:33 PM
@thefalconegeneral
Why do you believe you're qualified for the position you have been nominated to
Thank you for the question. During my various terms as Secretary of the Commonwealth of Lincoln, Clerk and Deputy Clerk of the U.S. House of Representatives, Secretary of the U.S. Senate, and as the sitting Parliamentarian of the U.S. House of Representatives, I have led preservation of documents and records for the appropriate bodies. As Clerk of the House, I worked with the Archivist to catalog bills into the online database, and continued these efforts as Speaker as well.

In these positions, I gained the skills needed to serve as the Archivist of the United States and believe I am fully prepared to take on the responsibilities of the office.
ID: 1214324933191270463
thefalconegeneral
09:34 PM
Can you tell us a bit about your experience in the preservation of documents
ID: 1214325178511790131
Corey Clark
09:51 PM
@thefalconegeneral
Can you tell us a bit about your experience in the preservation of documents
Thank you for the question, but if I may ask for clarification of what you are asking?
ID: 1214329506051915837
Corey Clark
09:52 PM
Is the honorable Senator asking for more in-depth information about the times I spoke about earlier?
ID: 1214329690605486091
thefalconegeneral
09:59 PM
Can you tell us and list examples of your experience in the preservation of documents
ID: 1214331392864030852
Konnor Harris
02:13 AM
Following on that, what is the best method, in your opinion, of archiving documents that are important to our nation‚Äôs history?
ID: 1214395240287436900
Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
02:22 AM
What plans would you have as Acrhivist if confirmed?
ID: 1214397482923065404
Corey Clark
07:41 PM
@thefalconegeneral
Can you tell us and list examples of your experience in the preservation of documents
Certainly! As House Clerk and as Speaker, I worked with spreadsheets to catalog all of the bills and resolutions that were in the House. With them, I tracked the status of different bills and retained amended copies in the filing system to ensure the correct copy was available to the public.
ID: 1214659119747694725
Corey Clark
07:42 PM (edited)
@Konnor Harris
Following on that, what is the best method, in your opinion, of archiving documents that are importa
The importance of retaining physical copies is something the administration has always been wonderful at and I'd like to continue that, but I would like to see more digital-izing of documents so that anyone can access the documents even if they aren't presently at the archives.
ID: 1214659380721745960
Corey Clark
07:43 PM
The administration has been digital-izing documents, but I would hope to see quicker uploading of documents.
ID: 1214659560321847346
Konnor Harris
07:45 PM
And after you digitize the documents, what are your plans for physical storage?
ID: 1214659998769225769
Corey Clark
07:47 PM (edited)
@Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
What plans would you have as Acrhivist if confirmed?
As Archivist, my main goal aside from regular duties would be to expand outreach to students across the nation and talk with educational leadership about ways to get more students visiting the archives.
ID: 1214660698475466802
Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
07:49 PM
Alright. I don't have any other questions at this time.

Thank you Congressman, or Mr. Vice President, for being here.
ID: 1214661107634012210
Corey Clark
07:50 PM
@Konnor Harris
And after you digitize the documents, what are your plans for physical storage?
I believe the current practices of storage have been working well so far, but I would look into revisiting security for documents and protection against floods and fire to ensure that current practices are up to both standard of Congress and of NARA as a whole.
ID: 1214661384567259217
Corey Clark
07:50 PM
@Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
Alright. I don't have any other questions at this time. Thank you Congressman, or Mr. Vice Presiden
Thank you President Pluribus

ID: 1214665389452034089
Konnor Harris
08:13 PM
@Corey Clark
Could the Senator clarify their question?
Should internal documents made by an administration (which may contain classified material) be left at the White House for pickup, should the President‚Äôs staff turn them all over at the end of the term, should original copies be turned over immediately to NARA and duplicates kept on site which are destroyed at the end of a term, et cetera.
ID: 1214667089336606851
Konnor Harris
08:14 PM (edited)
Let‚Äôs just say hypothetically, a President left and took hundreds of classified documents with them, and stored them in a bathroom or other easily accessible location. What do you believe would be the best way to prevent that from happening?
‚≠ê 10
<:trolllaugh:1068728637634904075> 4
ID: 1214667441129521192
Corey Clark
08:34 PM
@Konnor Harris
Let‚Äôs just say hypothetically, a President left and took hundreds of classified documents with them,
// replying to both parts in one
It would be best for them to keep the documents until the end of the term, and then a member of the staff transfers custody over at the end of the term. There is no simple way to prevent classified documents being kept by an administration post-term, but NARA should always work to ensure the laws and policies around such documents are carried out to the extent permitted.

09:27 PM

ID: 1214754517095153704

S.9 - Prison Library Grants Establishment Act
ID: 1242496410591432815
Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
02:43 AM
Mr. Chairman, now is a better time to ever to talk about S.7.

I've talked to the Senator about amending the bill to make it more in line with practices concerning competitive bidding if he so desired a private company leading the charge on high speed rail in Lincoln.

My support for that was nessecary for me to even cosponsor at the very least in the first place.

I am still speaking to the Senator, the author, about amendments.

I ask that more time be given to consider S.7, at least while I get word from the author as to the amendments he is willing to accept.

If he does not accept such amendments, I'd say the bill as is is dead in the water, of course.

Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
09:00 PM
I think overall this legislation is alright, I think I just have a technical amendment.

However, 500 to 600 million over the course of fiscal months 2024 to 2028 is hefty, and and I don't quite sit well with a reduction of 100 million in other nuclear related projects, which is broad and could include things like nuclear waste management reaserch and others.

I think for the sake of other programs, the spending should be reduced by at least 150 million.

üëã 1
ID: 1245847145332871178
Toasted
09:14 PM (edited)
@Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
The former myself and at least the Minority staff will need to do some research on and it may be ben
If I could respond. First, on forming a public-private partnership with power plant companies - section 3(1) authorizes the secretary to "(1) enter into agreements or contracts with any Federal, State, or local agency or private organization,...for the purpose of furthering the development and research of FNRs or FBRs"; the legislation has that covered already.

secondly - the reasoning behind the high fiscal allocation is twofold and is as follows: firstly, breeder and fusion reactors have remained largely experimental technologies for the time being, although they have the potential to change the face, sustainability, efficiency, etc. of nuclear energy. a large portion of the research that would therefore be conducted as a result of the act would not be merely the facilitation of current nuclear reactors but rather large leaps in scientific progress and a sizable financial push for its conduct would seem appropriate. 2, the bill authorizes the secretary to provide grants not exceeding $40M as was mentioned in the first paragraph of my reply - to provide adequate grants for an adequate number of partners as well as to conduct vital research within the department as described in my first point would seem to require such funds.
ID: 1245847776890191983
Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
09:14 PM
If it was a tens of millions I'd be slightly more inclined to pass this through but half a billion is a lot of money.

(e) ‚ÄúThe Under Secretary‚Äù shall refer to The Under Secretary for Science in the United States Department of Energy.

(1) enter into agreements or contracts with any Federal, State, or local agency or private organizations on behalf of the Department, for the purpose of furthering the development, research and construction of DFs within the state of Pacifica.

(2) award grants not exceeding ~~$60,000,000~~ $10,000,000 each to such federal, state, or local agencies, or research institutions, to further the development, research, or construction of DFs within the state of Pacifica.

@Senate General Welfare Committee

ID: 1254460989567406135
Amb. Pluribus (D-LN)
03:42 PM
I believe Leader Holland's dismissal of EV as a potential alternative as any alternative to gas vehicles is short sighted. EV's like other technology is developing constantly to make sure it is produced in as efficient a way as possible and not using as much lithium.

Additionally, we must compare EV's to what is currently dominating the market. Expanding infrastructure for EV's will make them more competitive, thus allowing the free market, the American people, to decide how they traverse the road.

Surely Mr. Holland would agree that EV's by emissions overall are better than the gas guzzling suburbans both he and myself and the very chairman of this committee ride in to work.

S.11 - Education Enhancement Act of 2024
178th CONGRESS 1st Session S.11 IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES JUNE 22, 2024 Introduced by Senator Norman Nord, for himself, Mr. Sun of Olympia. IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES OF THE UNITED STATES Introduced by Mr. Silveira of Olympia. A BILL To improve the status of American educa...
ID: 1254469291600908440
Nord íâ£íåííãºíàæíäëíåì
04:28 PM
S.11 is necessary for the progress of America. It is becomming more and more obvious that we are falling behind in terms of education. I have spoken with middle school teachers who have to deal with students that lack basic mathematic or literary skills.

No longer will we allow our kids to grow up dumb and uneducated. This bill will enhance the state of education in America by establishing stringent standards on education and state testing. There will be an actual standard to pass classes. If a student doesn't know the material, they will re take it until they learn.

Education is one of the most important aspects of society, and so improving it should be a no brainer. With that, I ask Unanimous Consent to refer this bill to the senate floor.

ID: 1255976602828013610
Toasted
08:02 PM (edited)
I move to amend S.11 in the following manner.

SECTION 9. APPROPRIATIONS AUTHORIZATION

(1) There is authorized to be appropriated to carry out Sections 4, 5, and 6 of this act, $80,000,000 for fiscal year 2024, and $15,000,000 for each succeeding fiscal year.

(2) There is authorized to be appropriated to carry out Section 10 of this act, $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2024, and $20,000,000 for each succeeding fiscal year.*

SECTION 10. SCHOOL BASED MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES

(1) The Secretary shall organize a commission to review mental health in schools across the United States, which shall --

(a) evaluate each LEA based off criteria including but not limited to;
(i) existing funds available to school mental health services
(ii) the overall state of mental health in schools
(iii) and other criteria as the Secretary, or commission with approval of the Secretary, should determine;

(b) based on their evaluation of each LEA, recommend an amount to be granted to them from the funding authorized in Section 9(2) of this act);

(c) prepare a report on their findings, evaluations and recommendations from carrying out Sections 10(1)(a) and 10(1)(b) of this act, no later than 8 months following the enactment of this act.

(2) the Secretary shall then, with the findings provided in the report by the commission mentioned in Section 10(1) of this act, authorize the grant of funds as authorized by 9(2) of this act, for the purposes of assisting school-based mental health services, hiring more mental health professionals in schools, and creating community partnerships to provide additional support.

(3) The commission established in 10(1) shall prepare a biennial report on the use of funds granted under subsection 10(2) to ensure LEAs are using the funds properly and shall notify the Secretary if it feels otherwise. The Secretary may amend or discontinue grant allocations to a school at any time.
ID: 1255976644997550130
Toasted
08:08 PM (edited)
I also move to amend Section 6 and 8 of S.11 as follows:

SECTION 6

(3) If a LEA fails to implement the enhanced academic standards within a timeframe determined by the Secretary, and failure as determined by the Secretary, federal educational funding as authorized in Section 9(1) of this act shall be withheld from said LEA until the Secretary re-evaluates the LEA as having followed its direction.

SECTION 8. ENACTMENT
This act shall take effect ~~on the date that is 6 months~~ immediately after the ~~date of~~ enactment of this act.

SECTION 10. SCHOOL BASED MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES

(1) The Secretary shall organize a commission to review mental health in schools across the United States, which shall --

...

(d) be composed of at least 9 education professionals, who either work, have worked, or have a degree in education. Each member shall be appointed to a term of one year by the Secretary. Members may serve multiple consecutive terms.
(i) Membership of the board shall be paid as a position on the fifth level of the Executive Schedule.

(a) Assist SEAs in developing and implementing more advanced and comprehensive state testing that aligns with the enhanced academic standards established under Section 4.

They MAKE guidelines

S.3 - Education Enhancement Act of 2024
178th CONGRESS 1st Session S.3 IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES JUNE 22, 2024 Introduced by Senators James Sun of Olympia and Norman Nord of Pacifica IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES OF THE UNITED STATES Introduced by Mr. Silveira of Olympia. A BILL To improve the status of American edu...
ID: 1262206086094651412
Kaylalicious
12:48 AM
Present
ID: 1262209157876945006
Kaylalicious
12:17 PM
I urge my colleagues to pass this bill, which will empower children and give them the resources to be the leaders of the future.
ID: 1262382543882158243
Sen. Diana Allar (D-WA)
12:41 PM
In opposition to my colleague from Pacifica, definitely not. This bill, while well-intentioned, dumbs down a previously set national standard and vaguely institutes a federal standard and educational curriculum much worse than what we currently have in our country. I said on the campaign trail that I promised to leave government once I fulfilled the promise of making every institution of public education (IPE) a palace of knowledge and wonder, and this bill will just do the opposite, for many reasons.

1) The sloppy writing makes for a dangerous outcome. While already tearing apart and mutilating the educational standard we have previously set, the bill withdraws all fundings accorded in the act from schools receiving federal grants if they fail to meet the "standards set".

2) Vague standards at secretarial discretion. The Department of Education, under the Department of Social Services, is supposed to monitor the schools and release reports on their standards, but it is not dictated what the standard of performance should be. You could have one child held back a grade and have all of the funding in this act ripped from the school the kid was held back in. Removing money from schools that are still struggling and failing to implement the standards WE set will only encourage them to regress and perform worse.

3) Passing money around the bottom barrel. The bill states that the money that comes from underperforming schools will go to schools performing in the 20th percentile and economically underdeveloped schools therein, when those are already the schools that are performing the worst and will have the hardest time implementing these standards. If you rip the temporary grants away from these schools before they are able to implement these lackluster standards, then they will have an even harder time doing so and it will generally worsen the standard of education in the United States.

4) LEA is a weird name. It's called an IPE, Institution of Public Education, or a Public Education Institution (PEI).

5) All of these are normal standards, already set in better detail by the Common Core k-12 curriculum, which is of more widespread use than any other public education curriculum in the nation. "Proficiency in arithmetic and simple mathematics by the completion of primary school, proficiency in basic Algebra (Algebra I) by the completion of middle school, and proficiency in intermediate Algebra (Algebra II), intermediate Geometry, and Precalculus by the completion of secondary school. " is quite literally a downgrade.

6) This bill creates new standardized testing to meet these standards, which will add another mid-year burden onto students at a time when there are calls from each corner of the educational field to ban standardized testing. Which, I agree with, by the way. Standardized testing holds every student to the same standard when some learn at different paces than others.

7) There are literally no standards set as to how the school is to meet these standards. Like I said previously, a child could be the only one in the school to get held back and the secretary could theoretically make the decision to rip all funding allocated by this act from the school and move it around. It's a game of musical chairs with checks and dollar bills, and we won't stand for that.

8) Mental health funding for schools should be confined to a separate piece of legislation, one that I am happy to introduce if need be. The mental health of our children is a top priority of the United States Government, but this is not the legislation in which we need to fix that issue.

So, with that being said, I will be voting nay, and I urge my colleagues to do the same. Thank you.
ID: 1262388578512535642

We should let the Secretary and the experts provide these standards, knowing that they will be crafted with the best intentions of our children at heart.

There is no specificity, and, by and large, this curriculum is already intact throughout our nation. This bill is a useless waste of 80 million dollars that could very well be better coordinated and executed with meaningful change instead of just show for political points. The Senators tried to recreate No Child Left Behind with this act, and instead, they are leaving children behind.

02:11 PM
This bill does not establish checks and balances on the secretary's standards when deciding the course of action on the educational enhancement grants. Instead, it gives the department full discretion over the matter and does not institute Congressional oversight on the actions. The only way we can stop the Secretary from setting unfair standards is by killing the bill now or repealing it later. The only people who will have a say in this are the State Department of Educations and the federal one. We have absolutely zero say over any of this, Senator. It has absolutely nothing to do with undermining the President and everything to do with undermining the children of this nation and the sanctity of the institution of Government.

S.5 - A.I.D.S Act
179th CONGRESS 1st Session S.5 IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES JULY 13, 2024 Introduced by Senator Sun of Olympia (for himself, Norman Nord of Pacifica, Mr. Anka of Lincoln) A BILL To establish an allocation pool in order to give out grants up to $10,000 dollars for assisting developing...
ID: 1262439311488323594
Senator Axel! ‚≠ê
04:03 PM
Debate will be open for 24 hours
ID: 1262439385828163674
Sen. Diana Allar (D-WA)
04:42 PM
I will be rising in opposition to this legislation, and I heavily urge all of my colleagues to do the same for the better of the country's economy and financial security.

Here's why.

The AIDS act, while well intentioned, attempts to institute an entirely new government institution for the purpose of subsidizing demand, something that has been tried in the past and has failed miserably. Dishing out 30 million dollars a year to give ten extra thousand dollars to small government is a project which requires extreme precision in its introduction and implementation, something we do not see in this legislation. The Small Business Administration already does everything in its power to create a more conducive environment for the owners of small companies, and this will throw a wrench in their side.

Plus, anyone who's owned a small business knows that ten thousand dollars runs dry like *snaps fingers* that. It's a good boost to get some advertising going, but it also doesn't mean much in the present market. It's a large sum of money to spread across so many companies, too. Especially considering the fact that this bill extends to companies between two employees and four hundred ninety-nine employees. Two person companies using a $10,000 grant is $5,000 per employee, and then 499 employees using a grant of that same value is $20.04 per employee. The bill has restrictions in place that direct the hypothetical "commission" to institute a financial report requirement to ensure that the money is used for its intended purpose, but the regulations set are vague and could very well be determined ambiguous by a court.

The bill itself is ambiguous in nature, really. It says that the commission can grant up to $10,000 per applicant, but that in some circumstances up to $350,000 in the whole lifetime of the company is acceptable. THREE HUNDRED FIFTY THOUSAND DOLLARS? I get it's for the entire lifespan of the company, but that is absolutely unacceptable. If you are so god awful at managing your business that you need over $10,000 dollars from the government REPEATEDLY to keep it going, then maybe you should not be managing a business. The bill directs the commission and the SBA at large to offer advice and counseling to business owners, but that is also vague and indistinct of the practices of mentorship in which they are to provide, regardless of if the subjects are provided or not.

Another thing is that the bill bans funding from being allocated to independent contractors when the money is strictly for advertisement, business growth, and development, which can be seen as a discriminatory practice by some. If you're going to make a futile attempt to support businesses and the working man, at least support all of them. The bill does not specify whether or not grants can be repeated, it instead sets fast and loose monetary standards for the commission to adhere to without further regulation or guidelines attached, minus the eligibility for application.

We cannot play fast and loose with our economy. Reckless spending leads to a wrecked economy. Like I said previously, the Republican party is playing a game of musical chairs with checks and dollar bills. We, the loyal opposition in the Senate and the majority in the House, will not stand for it. I have been in talks with Speaker Pluribus, and we will be working on a sensible alternative to this disastrous bill which will end just the same as the Community Reinvestment Act, Tax Reform Act, Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, the Troubled Asset Relief Program, And the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA, as known by many).

We will be doing everything in our power to block this legislation, should it come to a floor vote. We mustn't allow history to repeat itself. Thank you, Madam Chair, and the honorable members of this committee.
ID: 1262449252622405662
Sen. Diana Allar (D-WA)
04:44 PM (edited)
The Republican President-Elect is trying to spend like a tax and spend Democrat. We, the people, will not allow it.

Sen. Diana Allar (D-WA)

Thank you.
ID: 1262449773072482386
Kaylalicious
05:59 PM
The senators before me seem to have engaged in an attempt to play party games with the legislation of our nation and what seems to be a deliberate misconstruance of the republican party agenda and bills. I have to first say that it pains me, as a member of this senate who has looked upon its proceedings with great admiration, that this body, once previously almost unburdened by the plague of partisanship during recent congresses, and marked by a spirit of cooperation, has at last fallen sick to that ailment of party politics which runs deep in the blood of democracy. No matter - the topic as of now are the fallacious arguments at hand which my democratic colleague, Ms. Allar, has presented in regards to this education bill before our committee.

I should first provide some background to the bill at hand. This is a bill that has passed the senate during our last session with three thirds of senators voting; a bill that through days of reconciliation and amendment was found agreeable by both parties. It was the Minority Leader, Mr. Pluribus, who first asked to put the bill up to a vote. Ms. Moctezuma never breathed a word in commentary. I find it a little suspicious that it is now they choose to oppose it.

Regardless, their arguments aren‚Äôt even based in fact. The first argument made by Ms. Allar is, ‚Äúwhile already tearing apart and mutilating the educational standard we have previously set, the bill withdraws all fundings accorded in the act from schools receiving federal grants if they fail to meet the 'standards' set". What this argument shows is that Ms. Allar was failed by the English department of her school because she evidently does not know how to read. She appears to be referring to Section 6(3) of this act, which reads, ‚ÄúIf a LEA fails to implement the enhanced academic standards within a timeframe determined by the Secretary, and failure as determined by the Secretary, federal educational funding as authorized in Section 9(1) of this act shall be withheld from said LEA until the Secretary re-evaluates the LEA as having followed its direction.‚Äù This is VERY different from stripping away all federal grants from a school, like she seems to be implying - it‚Äôs funding, not all funding, but funding as authorized in Section 9(1) of the act. You see, what the bill does is give extra money to our schools, and if they fail to meet the standard, they are only cut off from the *extra* money, not all federal grants. And the senator from Olympia somehow failing to understand this shows just how urgently we need to institute educational reform.

Their second argument? ‚ÄúVague standards at secretarial discretion‚Ä¶ it is not dictated what the standard of performance should be. You could have one child held back a grade and have all of the funding in this act ripped from the school the kid was held back in. Removing money from schools that are still struggling and failing to implement the standards WE set will only encourage them to regress and perform worse.‚Äù This argument, once again, demonstrates the inability of the Senator from Olympia, to read. The act does not force students to reach a level of academic achievement. This act does not require students to test will. The act does not even force the student to pass the grade - in fact, the act is deliberately meant to help hold back kids that need it - see Section 5(1)(b), where it is encouraged to hold kids back that aren‚Äôt meeting standards. The only measure is whether the school has instituted the bill-mandated curriculum, and is receiving its testing, or not. It is not a measure of performance. It is a measure of, ‚Äúdid you institute the curriculum or not?" Any school that does not institute a curriculum - a relatively costless transition - will be turning down free grant money, and no school is barred from doing so or not doing so.
ID: 1262468535062364250
Kaylalicious
06:00 PM
Their third argument. ‚ÄúThe bill states that the money that comes from underperforming schools will go to schools performing in the 20th percentile and economically underdeveloped schools therein, when those are already the schools that are performing the worst and will have the hardest time implementing these standards. If you rip the temporary grants away from these schools before they are able to implement these lackluster standards, then they will have an even harder time doing so and it will generally worsen the standard of education in the United States.‚Äù Well, Ms. Allar, they will not have a very hard time implementing these standards because these standards are not dependent on a school‚Äôs financial resources or academic performance. Implementing these standards are dependent on a school willing to tweak their academic curriculum a bit and get the grant money for their kids.

‚Äú4) LEA is a weird name. It's called an IPE, Institution of Public Education, or a Public Education Institution (PEI).‚Äù I would like to ask if Ms. Allar is okay because this is quite an odd argument for a senator to present. The name doesn‚Äôt matter. This might be the most partisan thing that I‚Äôve seen since the blocking of Obama‚Äôs supreme court justices.

‚Äú5) All of these are normal standards, already set in better detail by the Common Core k-12 curriculum, which is of more widespread use than any other public education curriculum in the nation. ‚ÄúProficiency in arithmetic and simple mathematics by the completion of primary school, proficiency in basic Algebra (Algebra I) by the completion of middle school, and proficiency in intermediate Algebra (Algebra II), intermediate Geometry, and Precalculus by the completion of secondary school.‚Äù is quite literally a downgrade.‚Äù

What this argument demonstrates is that Senator Allar seems to be completely out of touch with the American people and education. These are not downgrades. These standards are somewhat more advanced than the common core ones. For example, Common Core does not mandate the completion of Algebra I by the end of 8th grade; that is set aside for high school. Furthermore, if they are the same standards, Ms. Allar‚Äôs complaint about the curriculum of some schools having a ‚Äúhardest time implementing these standards‚Äù should be redundant because then they are the same standards and nothing would change.

This next argument irks me a little. ‚ÄúThis bill creates new standardized testing to meet these standards, which will add another mid-year burden onto students at a time when there are calls from each corner of the educational field to ban standardized testing. Which, I agree with, by the way. Standardized testing holds every student to the same standard when some learn at different paces than others.‚Äù She first calls it a burden and then proceeds to say she agrees with it - which - alright - I take it that she agrees with this section and I won‚Äôt cover it further.

‚ÄúThere are literally no standards set as to how the school is to meet these standards. Like I said previously, a child could be the only one in the school to get held back and the secretary could theoretically make the decision to rip all funding allocated by this act from the school and move it around. It's a game of musical chairs with checks and dollar bills, and we won't stand for that.‚Äù There is very much a standard, and it‚Äôs ‚Äúdid the school implement the thing we wanted them to implement‚Äù? That is what compliance to the standard means, since the standard is a curriculum - did you implement the curriculum.
ID: 1262468749886226572
Kaylalicious
06:00 PM
‚Äú8) Mental health funding for schools should be confined to a separate piece of legislation, one that I am happy to introduce if need be. The mental health of our children is a top priority of the United States Government, but this is not the legislation in which we need to fix that issue.‚Äù It does not surprise me that a rich suburban living white lady out of touch with her constituency should try and stall mental health investment to a later bill simply out of want of compartmentalization. Law is law and law is the same law enacted now here or enacted tomorrow there. Only, for the good of our children, such a law should be enacted ASAP.

For these reasons, I encourage my colleagues to ignore the partisan bickering of the democrats, recognize the bill on its merits and their arguments on their grave fallacies, and vote aye for this bill, as will I. I move to cloture debate on S.11 and bring it to a vote on referral. I yield.

Sen. Diana Allar (D-WA)

I object and I have a point of order
ID: 1262469432777638039
Sen. Diana Allar (D-WA)
06:23 PM
@Kaylalicious
The senators before me seem to have engaged in an attempt to play party games with the legislation o
I'm not even going to address the absurd claim that anything I am saying is based in partisanship. Shame on you for making this about party affiliation whatsoever.

First of all, if you want to defend a poorly written education bill, get your facts straight. I stated several times that I knew it was not ALL federal funding being pulled from schools. If you want a school to thrive, and you are going to give it money to do so, ripping that money right back out because they didn't do it in time will achieve the exact opposite of your goal. If you're gonna twist my words around, do it right.

What you people tried to construct here was a word salad version of common core to make it look like you care about education, but really you are just trying to revert us back to a period in which our education standards failed our children worse than yours did, obviously. Also, if the legislation's only standard was that the school instituted the bill, then why doesn't it say that? This could very easily be interpreted as the bill requiring students to perform at a better rate under this curriculum, because the way you guys wrote it was so awful and ambiguous.

Also, denying that schools with less financial resources have worse academic performance is just sad. We live in a society in which your class determines your standard of education, and these people want to make it worse. You are literally worsening the standard of education for many children. Our public education curriculum is currently fine where it is, it just needs reforms to better suit the different levels each student is asses to be at and focus more on vocational training. All this does is reinstitute common core but worse. Also, educational curriculums are not the business of the federal government. You cannot set a standard and force all schools in the country to comply. the LEA thing was a personal thing.

I'm not even going to address your claim that I'm out of touch with the American people, Kayla. I have endured trials in my life that you nor no one in this room have matched or accomplished. I have been on the ground working for a living, getting my education, starting up a business, and anything else any everyday American has had to do to survive on their own. I have went through our public education system and I know how it works. It is not conducive to students, and it is certainly not conducive to these lackluster "changes" you are attempting to implement.

It seems we are coming to the conclusion that *you* are the one who can't read, Miss Whitmer. I said I agree with banning standardized testing, not standardized testing as a whole. My next sentence rebukes standardized testing. If you're going to come for me, do it the right way. You're acting very incompetent right now, and the American people will not stand for it.

If that is what the standard was set to be, then say that. Do not leave it open to interpretation. This is how we get our bills landed in court.

As many of you know, I have struggled with my mental health in the past, specifically during the divorce of my husband, death of my mother, and death of my daughter. I have long endured challenges with Depression, moderate to severe, and I have done what it takes to get better and move on with my life, learning from the lessons along the way through my struggles. I want to make the mental health portion separate because it is the only thing in this bill actually aimed towards helping the children. Shame on you for putting on a partisan show and making a fool out of yourself and your colleagues.

The only partisan bickering here is you attacking my character, Miss Whitmer. This bill has no merits except for helping the mental health of children. Vote nay, for the sanctity of the institution of American education.

ID: 1263147510940041216
Senator Axel! ‚≠ê

07:39 AM
Following has been referred and is open for debate: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1S8gVyuG5jTfAeTshZ_KNWGn3pz__FQTWWtZ3ESDBQWY/edit
S.1 - E.D.P Act (180th)
180th CONGRESS 1st Session S.1 IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES AUGUST 13, 2024 Introduced by Senator Norman Nord of Pacifica(for himself) A BILL To revitalize and encourage domestic production within the United States of America via subsidization. Be it enacted by the Senate and House...
ID: 1273184212580569191
derek | „Éá„É¨„ÉÉ„ÇØ FREE ALDERAAN
10:40 AM
I have some problems with S.1. The first problem is with the definition of a small business, which is normally defined by the SBA with either an employee limit or a receipt limit. For a law business to qualify, it would need to have lower average annual receipts than something like used car dealerships. For the majority of businesses, they must qualify by making less than a certain threshold in millions of dollars, and in fact, some have employee limits lower than 1500, especially manufacturing which this bill tries to provide grants to. As such, my first amendment moves to ensure consistency over US law by simply using the SBA definition, which differs from sector to sector.



I am also concerned about the actual way the bill goes about achieving its goal. There are already existing subsidy programs for small businesses, and this provides $160,000,000 for the 2025 fiscal year. I do genuinely question how the author of this bill came up with these numbers. There are almost 600,000 manufacturing small businesses, as well as over 100,000 mining, mineral extraction and quarrying small businesses, with a decent proportion of these being rare mineral extraction. When you also consider that it is not only small businesses that are eligible for grants, but are merely prioritised, which essentially means nothing. Small businesses should be the only ones eligible for these, and so that's what further amendments will do.

Typical grants can be $5000-$10000, meaning that ultimately, a very small number of these small businesses would be able to receive these grants without the program going over budget, making this seem more like a gimmick. There are already many, well funded grant programs for small businesses that we can put more in. I ultimately don't think this bill is particularly necessary and will be voting against it.

However, I believe this bill can be amended to try to achieve its purpose in a better way, and as such:


I move to make the following amendments:
To strike ‚Äúwith less than 1,500 employees‚Äù in Section 3(f) and replace it with ‚Äúdefined by the Small Business Administration as a small business‚Äù;
To strike ‚Äú32 days‚Äù wherever it appears and replace it with ‚Äú31 days‚Äù;
To insert a new subsection (g) in Section 3 reading:

> (g) An ‚Äúeligible entity‚Äù is one which meets the criteria in both Section 3(e) and 3(f)

To insert at the end of Section(5)(2)(f):

> (g) Whether the applicant is an eligible entity or not.

To strike Section 5(6) in its entirety and replace it with;

> (6) The Secretary shall have the authority to modify the list of eligible entities, including the ability to:

> (a) Remove sectors from the definition in Section 3(e);
> (b) Add sectors eligible under Section 3(e).
üíñ 1
ID: 1273229659722485783
derek | „Éá„É¨„ÉÉ„ÇØ FREE ALDERAAN
10:41 AM
I move to divide each of these individual amendments as well.

S. 3 To require Political Action Committees to disclose ownership information and release reports on ownership status bimonthly. IN THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES AUGUST 13, 2024 MRS. ALLAR of Olympia (for herself, MR. MILLER of Frontier,) introduced the following bill, which was r...

ID: 1273492965935026219
Nord íâ£íåííãºíàæíäëíåì
04:08 AM
@Nord íâ£íåííãºíàæíäëíåì
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1JWvMl3WuNW6uVG5lHHTXKR97AnlOZw-YBu42ryoHw64/edit?usp=sharing
There are many reasons I believe that S.3 requires further consideration from this committee. The first is that it is vague, unclear, and poorly written. While it has a noble cause, the wording leaves a lot to be desired.

For example, Section 5 of the bill states, ‚Äú In General ‚Äî All Political Committees shall disclose an annual report detailing the following: The legal identities of their ownership, including committee members and a total count of their overall membership; A ledger detailing all monetary expenses and revenues over 50 dollars; and A list of any individual(s) who donate 500 dollars or more to the political committee over the course of one calendar year.‚Äù

It does not state to whom the report is made. This is a glaring flaw in this bill, which must be fixed before this bill should ever pass. There are such mistakes.

The bill is called, ‚ÄúTracking Required Accountability Notices for Special Political Action Reports Ensuring Nonpartisan Control Yearly Act.‚Äù To require Political Action Committees to disclose ownership information and release reports on ownership status bimonthly.‚Äù

Bimonthly and Annual are two different time spans. This is an issue that will lead to confusion.

These are issues I hope to see fixed.

ID: 1273676681332133979
Nord íâ£íåííãºíàæíäëíåì
04:18 PM
I frankly think a report to the FEC with:
(I) The legal identities of their ownership, including committee members and a total count of their overall membership;
(II) A ledger detailing all monetary expenses and revenues over 50 dollars; and
(II)A list of any individual(s) who donate 500 dollars or more to the political committee over the course of one calendar year."

Is not very useful. FECA already mandates most of this.

52 USC 30102(c)

"The treasurer of a political committee shall keep an account of-

(1) all contributions received by or on behalf of such political committee;

(2) the name and address of any person who makes any contribution in excess of $50, together with the date and amount of such contribution by any person;

(3) the identification of any person who makes a contribution or contributions aggregating more than $200 during a calendar year, together with the date and amount of any such contribution;

(4) the identification of any political committee which makes a contribution, together with the date and amount of any such contribution; and

(5) the name and address of every person to whom any disbursement is made, the date, amount, and purpose of the disbursement, and the name of the candidate and the office sought by the candidate, if any, for whom the disbursement was made, including a receipt, invoice, or canceled check for each disbursement in excess of $200."

This means the third requirement is pretty much useless; contributions in excess of 500 are already reported.

52 USC 30104(b) covers reporting too. Expenses, and other financial information is already reported to the FEC and made public.

The only applicable part of the section would be the first; disclosure of ownership and committee membership.

ID: 1273678342750474332
Nord íâ£íåííãºíàæíäëíåì
04:23 PM
Political parties; campaign committees for candidates for federal, state or local office; and political action committees are all political organizations subject to tax under IRC section 527.

Section 527 organizations are generally required to file one or more of the following:

An initial notice
Periodic reports on contributions and expenditures
Annual income tax returns and
Annual information returns
ID: 1273678355102695568

Filing Requirements for Political Organizations | Internal Revenue ...
Political parties; campaign committees for candidates for federal, state or local office; and political action committees are all political organizations subject to tax under IRC section 527. Section 527 organizations are generally required to file one or more of the following:

ID: 1273678646724263987
Sen. Diana Allar (D-WA)
04:25 PM
Annual income tax returns and annual information returns notwithstanding the identities of donors exceeding the amounts set, nor does it include the actual meticulous finances of the Political Action Committees, rather the bigger picture.

Periodic reports on contributions and expenditures provide a snapshot of the financial health of organizations at regular intervals. They detail income, expenses, assets, liabilities, and cash flow. They are not meant to draw a picture as to where the money is coming from at large, yet how the money is spent and where it goes. S527 organizations do not have to disclose the name of small donors who exceed a set amount in donations. This bill requires them to do so.

A political organization which accepts a
contribution, or makes an expenditure, for an
exempt function during any calendar year
shall file with the Secretary either‚Äî
(A)(i) in the case of a calendar year in
which a regularly scheduled election is
held‚Äî
(I) quarterly reports, beginning with the
first quarter of the calendar year in which
a contribution is accepted or expenditure
is made, which shall be filed not later than
the fifteenth day after the last day of each
calendar quarter, except that the report
for the quarter ending on December 31 of
such calendar year shall be filed not later
than January 31 of the following calendar
year,
ID: 1273680459427090472

(II) a pre-election report, which shall be
filed not later than the twelfth day before
(or posted by registered or certified mail
not later than the fifteenth day before)
any election with respect to which the organization makes a contribution or expenditure, and which shall be complete as
of the twentieth day before the election,
and
(III) a post-general election report,
which shall be filed not later than the thirtieth day after the general election and
which shall be complete as of the twentieth day after such general election, and
(ii) in the case of any other calendar year,
a report covering the period beginning January 1 and ending June 30, which shall be filed
no later than July 31 and a report covering
the period beginning July 1 and ending December 31, which shall be filed no later than
January 31 of the following calendar year, or
(B) monthly reports for the calendar year,
beginning with the first month of the calendar year in which a contribution is accepted or expenditure is made, which shall be
filed not later than the twentieth day after
the last day of the month and shall be complete as if the last day of the month, except
that, in lieu of filing the reports otherwise
due in November and December of any year
in which a regularly scheduled general election is held, a pre-general election report
shall be filed in accordance with subparagraph (A)(i)(II), a post-general election report shall be filed in accordance with subparagraph (A)(i)(III), and a year end report
shall be filed not later than January 31 of
the following calendar year."

The IRS already has access to contributions and expenditures. As does the FEC.

@Sen. Diana Allar (D-WA)

This is a financial report; there may be a reference which I shall look for later but frankly it is not necessary for the IRS to posess such information.

ID: 1273683773132636385
Sen. Diana Allar (D-WA)
05:15 PM
With all due respect, sir, I believe you're mistaken.

They may have the information, but is it public record? I don't believe so. That is the aim of this bill. The people deserve to know where the money is being moved and why. They deserve to know who is making the decisions for them, in Congress or otherwise. That is why I have introduced this bill and that is exactly why I will spend as much time as it takes sitting in this committee to get it passed.

This bill accomplishes its purpose just fine. You are hurling a bunch of codes at me and they all miss the point; The point being the necessity for transparency in government. PAC ownership, nor the titles of PAC contributors, nor anything else listed in this bill is required to be public information. None of it at all. What this bill does is opens that window and allows people to see who is doing what.

If the institutions themselves will not do it, we will.

I'd have half a mind to state you are doing everything in your power to defend the PACs here, Senator Nord. For shame.

Hurling an incessant amount of laws my way that miss the point in its entirety. If you really had an issue with this bill, you would amend it yourself, instead of waiting for me to show up so you can do all but admonish me for the way this bill has been written. The point stands, the bill is effective, and the bill will pass, for the better of this society and for the better of government transparency. Soon, for these reasons, I will be reintroducing this bill with appropriate amendments, as the purpose seems to have been missed, but I would rather satisfy your concerns that continue to argue with you as to why you are wrong.

It speaks volumes the fact that you would rather bog yourself in campaign finance law while going back and forth with me than actually amend the bill to fit your desired outcome for the cause. I will be introducing the new version shortly.

ID: 1273691578304692306
Nord íâ£íåííãºíàæíäëíåì
06:53 PM
Firstly, items 2 and 3 on your requested report are avaliable.
Referring to the FEC website, <https://www.fec.gov/introduction-campaign-finance/how-to-research-public-records/pacs-parties-and-other-committees/>
Documents regarding finances, contributions, donations, etc. for PACs are avaliable to the general public.
The bill accomplishes what has already been done. If you wish to access the finance records of a PAC, you may go through the Public Records Office. I also recommend you consult the FEC website.

I am amenable to requiring the disclosure of PAC leadership, but I frankly think this bill should be re-written and re-introduced. It is necessary to ammend FECA in this case.
